# Question

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Here is the Julia function to achieve this:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    return replace(lowercase(strip(col)), r"[ -]" => "_")
end
```
This function first converts the input column name into lower case using the `lowercase` function, then strips any leading or trailing whitespaces using the `strip` function. After that, it replaces all spaces and hyphens with underscores using the `replace` function and a regular expression (`r"[ -]"`), which matches either a space or a hyphen.

You can call this function on a column name like so:
```julia
col = " My Column  "
cleaned_col = clean_column(col)
print(cleaned_col) # Outputs: my_column
```
